For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.

Given a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], the i-th coefficient a_i is called the coefficient of degree i.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a monomorphism if it is injective.
A proper ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a prime ideal if for elements $a, b \in R$, $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ implies $a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$.

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.
The unique smallest subfield $P$ of a field $K$, given by the intersection of all subfields in $K$, is referred to as the prime (sub)field in $K$.

A pair of fields $K \subset L$, where $K$ is a subfield of $L$, is called a field extension. $L$ is a field extending $K$ or an extension field of $K$, or simply that $L$ is a "field extension" of $K$.

An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.

Let $G$ be a group and $X$ a set. An action or an operation of $G$ on $X$ is a map $G \times X \longrightarrow X, \quad(g, x) \longmapsto g \cdot x$ such that: (i) $1 \cdot x=x$ for the unit element $1 \in G$ and for elements $x \in X$. (ii) $(g h) \cdot x=g \cdot(h \cdot x)$ for $g, h \in G, x \in X$.

A subgroup H of a finite group G is called a p-Sylow subgroup if H is a p-group such that p does not divide the index (G: H). This means there exist integers k, m in N satisfying ord H=p^k, as well as ord G=p^k m, where p does not divide m.
The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A monoid is a set equipped with an associative binary operation and an identity element. The product notation in monoids relies on the associative property of the monoid.
A cyclic group is a specific type of group. Therefore, the definition of a cyclic group depends on the definition of a group.

A ring monomorphism is a specific type of ring homomorphism, which in turn is a function between two rings. Therefore, the definition of a ring monomorphism depends on the definition of a ring and the concept of a function.
A prime ideal is a specific type of ideal in a ring. Therefore, the definition of a prime ideal depends on the definition of a ring.
A prime element is defined in the context of a unique factorization domain, which is a specific type of ring. Therefore, the definition of a prime element depends on the definition of a ring.
The prime subfield of a field is a specific type of subfield. Therefore, the definition of a prime subfield depends on the definition of a field.
A field extension is a pair of fields where one is a subfield of the other. Therefore, the definition of a field extension depends on the definition of a field.

An algebraic closure of a finite field is a field that contains the finite field and all its algebraic extensions. Therefore, the definition of an algebraic closure of a finite field depends on the definition of a field.
A group action is a map from the Cartesian product of a group and a set to the set. Therefore, the definition of a group action depends on the definition of a group and a set.
A p-Sylow subgroup is a specific type of subgroup in a finite group. Therefore, the definition of a p-Sylow subgroup depends on the definition of a group.
